11.text:
so they occur all around us all the time,
even if we don’t see them

15.text:
and therefore they're very likely
to be involved in a crime scene

18.text:
whether just accidentally or actually
because they have moved there

23.text: in response to some element of the crime scene.

26.text:
Looking at the body itself
it will be the pathologist

29.text:
who would look at the changes
in the body and try to determine

32.text: from the body what the post-mortem interval is.

34.text: But as an entomologist I can help the pathologist

37.text:
by looking, not at the body, but at
the insects that are feeding on and around the body.

43.text:
More precisely we are determining
a minimum post-mortem interval,

46.text:
that's basically the period that
the first insects found the body after death.

52.text:
Ordinarily in the summer months
in the UK with a body outdoors

57.text: it would be colonised by insects within 12 or 24 hours.

61.text: At the crime scene the main thing is recovery of evidence

66.text:
and I’ll do that at the scene
and then go back to the post-mortem

69.text: and carry on there if necessary.

73.text: We're interested not just on the insects on the body

76.text: but on insects that have been feeding on the body

78.text: and may already have dispersed away,

80.text:
because it makes good sense for these insects,
once they finish feeding,

84.text: not to hang around on the body because some other scavenger

87.text: may come and consume them as well as the body,

90.text: so they tend to disperse away.

92.text:
The gold standard forensic indicators are blowflies
and these are the ones that come in first,

97.text: immediately after the body's dead and starts to decompose.

102.text: They have an incredible sense of smell

105.text: and will arrive very, very quickly after death.

109.text:
The female fly will lay between
150 to 200 eggs on the suitable substrate,

115.text: and a human body is absolutely ideal for that.

118.text: Within about 24 hours in the UK summer

122.text:
those eggs will hatch and
they'll hatch into first stage larvae,

126.text: and these larvae are tiny, 1.5mm long.

130.text: Those larvae, though, are very hungry,

133.text:
they will crawl into the recesses
of the body and start feeding.

136.text:
Within 24 hours they themselves moult
into the second stage maggot

141.text: and then about another 24 hours later,

143.text: those will moult into the final, third stage maggot.

146.text: And that will feed for about three or four days.

149.text: When it's finished feeding it disperses away from the body

153.text: and looks for somewhere to pupate,

158.text:
It begins to harden itself and darken itself
until it forms a rugby ball shaped pupariam,

165.text: and inside that pupa the larval tissues are reassembled

169.text: through metamorphosis into an adult fly,

172.text: it’s a quite remarkable process that amazes me even today.

176.text:
After about 10 days in the UK summer
the adult fly is now ready to emerge.

182.text: And so the life cycle continues.

189.text: When blowflies respond to the odours of decomposition

193.text: they tend to navigate their way upwind through the odour plume

197.text: until they arrive at the scene.

200.text:
They will then use their visual
cues to land on the body

204.text:
and to move around and look for
the most suitable egg-laying site.

208.text:
Eggs are very susceptible to desiccation
so they tend to choose areas

212.text:
where the humidity is higher so
that tends to be the body orifices,

216.text: the eyes, the nose, the mouth,

219.text: and the genital/anal orifices if those are exposed.

223.text: And of course the humidity is maintained in those environments

228.text:
but it also affords the larvae the
opportunity to crawl into the body

232.text: and feed on the internal tissues,

236.text:
which are less well protected from
the insects' enzyme activity

240.text:
than the hard, tough, outer skin
that normally covers our bodies.

246.text:
So the focus of blowfly colonisation
tends to be on the head orifices.

260.text:
In this image just coming up here
we have a stillborn piglet.

264.text:
All you can see at the moment is the hotspot
and you can see a fly that’s just landed on it there.

270.text:
Surprisingly, although they’re coldblooded,
flies themselves generate quite a bit of heat

275.text: through their flight activity and muscle activity.

279.text:
The pig outline now is formed because
we’ve adjusted the temperature range

284.text: and you can see there’s a couple of flies moving around there.

287.text: We know they’re not the first flies to have found this piglet

289.text:
because that hotspot there is in fact where
there is already a small maggot mass developing.

298.text:
And what you can do actually is you can take
a series of images over a timescale from,

304.text:
in this case it was from day one to fourteen,
so a couple of weeks period.

309.text:
In the first six days or so, not a lot’s happening
because it takes a while for these first flies

315.text:
that have come in on day one to
lay their eggs, for the eggs to hatch.

319.text: - this was during a winter period.

321.text:
But on day six the temperature starts
to go up in the mouth of the pig

325.text:
and then over successive days that temperature hotspot
moves down through the body of the piglet

332.text: as its being consumed basically by a larval mass

336.text:
which is just rolling from the front end
to the back end of the piglet.

340.text:
And then after two weeks the piglet
is now completely cold and empty.

345.text:
All of the maggots have finished
feeding and they’ve moved away.

353.text:
So one of the accessibility issues we’ve been exploring
at the museum just in the last few months

357.text: is the impact of putting a body in a suitcase.

362.text: Is it possible for flies to find a body in a suitcase?

367.text:
Well, we found that using pig heads
as surrogate bodies from a butchers shop,

371.text: just pop them into a normal, carry-on suitcase

375.text:
and they delay the arrival of the flies
by one to three days or more,

381.text: However, the flies will arrive at the suitcase,

384.text: and they know that there’s a body in there.

386.text: And they will actually oviposit through the zip,

389.text: which most suitcases are sealed with these days.

393.text: The eggs will be laid into the suitcase

396.text: and in fact if they're just scattered around the zip

398.text:
the larvae themselves when they hatch
can crawl and enter the suitcase.

402.text:
So even hiding a body in a suitcase
won’t stop flies finding it

407.text:
and once they’ve found it they
will feed on the body in there.

410.text:
And in fact they will then try
to actually exit the suitcase as well,

415.text: and they can do this often through the holes in the frame

418.text: where the wheels of the suitcase are found.

420.text: So there's a whole range of factors out there in the environment

423.text: and even in the human factors of the environment

429.text: and make it a real challenge for a forensic entomologist
